docs.abstract: For decades, antitrust regulation has focused on the welfare of the consumer. Now a backlash over Big Tech’s power has regulators and scholars trying to reverse years of established doctrine.
docs.snippet: For decades, antitrust regulation has focused on the welfare of the consumer. Now a backlash over Big Tech’s power has regulators and scholars trying to reverse years of established doctrine.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Americans fear the future, they turn to antitrust action.

headline.main: To Take Down Big Tech, They First Need to Reinvent the Law
headline.print_headline: Antitrust Regulators Size Up Tech Giants

docs.abstract: Ms. Warren seeks to break up companies like Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook. And she has taken her fight to Silicon Valley.
docs.snippet: Ms. Warren seeks to break up companies like Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook. And she has taken her fight to Silicon Valley.
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts believes that the government must break up monopolies and promote competitive markets. That’s why she has taken aim at America’s largest tech companies.

headline.main: Elizabeth Warren on Breaking Up Big Tech

docs.abstract: The tech cold war is heating up. U.S. companies that depend on the giant China market are preparing themselves for the fallout.
docs.snippet: The tech cold war is heating up. U.S. companies that depend on the giant China market are preparing themselves for the fallout.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Silicon Valley looks west to China, it sees many things. More than a billion hungry consumers. A cheap source of labor. A competitor, partner, supplier and security risk.

headline.main: As China Takes Aim, Silicon Valley Braces for Pain
headline.print_headline: As China Takes Aim, Silicon Valley Braces for Pain

byline.original: By David Streitfeld and Don Clark

docs.abstract: Plus, Uber will give rude customers the boot, and a victory for gender-neutral parental leave.
docs.snippet: Plus, Uber will give rude customers the boot, and a victory for gender-neutral parental leave.
docs.lead_paragraph: Happy June! And sorry about your stock portfolio, which probably isn’t looking too hot after President Trump’s latest tariff threats. Here’s what you need to know about the week’s business news.

headline.main: The Week in Business: A Surprise Tariff War, and the Future of iPhone Screens

docs.abstract: The iPhone maker is adding patents and 2,200 Intel employees as it tries to reduce dependency on another chip maker, Qualcomm.
docs.snippet: The iPhone maker is adding patents and 2,200 Intel employees as it tries to reduce dependency on another chip maker, Qualcomm.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple said on Thursday that it would buy most of Intel’s smartphone-modem business for $1 billion, aiding its push to gain more control over faster wireless technology in iPhones.

headline.main: Apple Pays $1 Billion for Part of Intel’s Modem Business
headline.print_headline: Apple to Pay $1 Billion For Key Piece of Intel

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Don Clark

docs.abstract: And what that tells us about the fate of Apple in China.
docs.snippet: And what that tells us about the fate of Apple in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: I got my first iPhone during Chinese New Year in early 2012. It wasn’t anything I’d aspired to own. I wasn’t particularly techy, nor could I afford the brand as a graduate with a starting salary.

headline.main: Why My Chinese Dad Switched From an iPhone to a Huawei
headline.print_headline: Why My Chinese Dad Quit His iPhone

docs.abstract: The formal declaration by a bipartisan group of state officials adds investigative muscle to the intensifying scrutiny of the tech giant.
docs.snippet: The formal declaration by a bipartisan group of state officials adds investigative muscle to the intensifying scrutiny of the tech giant.
docs.lead_paragraph: The state attorneys general from four dozen states officially declared on Monday that they were beginning investigations into the market power and corporate behavior of big tech companies.

headline.main: Google Antitrust Investigation Outlined by State Attorneys General
headline.print_headline: States Join Rising Scrutiny Of Big Tech Companies

docs.abstract: Apple’s announcement ended a monthslong public dance with the White House over tariffs and the company’s ability to build products in the United States.
docs.snippet: Apple’s announcement ended a monthslong public dance with the White House over tariffs and the company’s ability to build products in the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple will make its new Mac Pro computer in Texas after the Trump administration agreed to waive tariffs on some of its Chinese-made parts, the company said on Monday.

headline.main: Apple Keeps Making Computer in Texas After Tariff Waivers
headline.print_headline: Apple Secures Tariff Waivers to Stay in Texas

docs.abstract: Some of tech’s biggest names had founders in their teens. But new research shows that for fast-growing start-ups in the U.S., the average age was 45.
docs.snippet: Some of tech’s biggest names had founders in their teens. But new research shows that for fast-growing start-ups in the U.S., the average age was 45.
docs.lead_paragraph: It took an entrepreneur to reimagine the mundane home thermostat as an object of beauty — and then to make a fortune based on that vision.

headline.main: Founders of Successful Tech Companies Are Mostly Middle-Aged
headline.print_headline: High-Flying Tech Has a Touch of Gray

docs.abstract: With companies racing to develop Shazam for art, we see what instant-identification apps really add to your experience in museums and galleries.
docs.snippet: With companies racing to develop Shazam for art, we see what instant-identification apps really add to your experience in museums and galleries.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the Betty Cuningham gallery on the Lower East Side recently, I noticed an arresting painting: It showed a nude woman curled against a window, asleep, with the old New Yorker Hotel and Empire State Building in view and a fish above her, hanging or floating. I opened a smartphone app called Magnus, snapped a quick picture, and clicked “Use.” Seconds later, I got that addictive, satisfying click. The app had found a match.

headline.main: Wondering Who Did That Painting? There’s an App (or Two) for That
headline.print_headline: Apps With an Eye For Art’s Back Story
